metadata.titleEn: Distribution maps of crop planting areas in the North China Plain (2001-2018)
metadata.description:
The North China Plain is an important food production area in China, with a large area of cropland and a complex planting structure. Accurately identifying the distribution of typical crops in this area and tracking the dynamic changes of planting structure are fundamental for detecting crop growth, evaluating crop irrigation water consumption and optimizing agricultural water resources allocation.
    This study used Fourier transform to obtatin the amplitudes and phases of the 0-5 harmonics of the MOD13Q1 NDVI data. Based on the field sample points and maximum likelihood supervised classification, the planting area of 6 typical crops (winter wheat-summer maize; winter wheat-rice; other double cropping systems; spring maize; cotton; other single cropping systems) in the North China Plain from 2001 to 2018 was identified. The identification results accuracy were evaluated  through confusion matrix, comparison with the winter wheat planting area in the county-level statistical yearbook, and comparison with the proportion of winter wheat extracted by Landsat images, all of which showed good performance and high accuracy.
    The data can be applied to related research and analysis on crop production, irrigation water consumption estimation, and groundwater protection in the North China Plain.
metadata.instructions:
(1) Data naming: The distribution map of crop planting areas is stored in raster data format (tif file), and the file name is "classresult_13q1_XX.tif", where "calssresult_13q1" represents the classification result using MOD13Q1 NDVI data, and "XX" is the year , spanning from 2001 to 2018, one picture per year. For example, "classresult_13q1_2001.tif" is the distribution map of crop planting areas in the North China Plain in 2001, which contains typical 6 types of crop distribution grids.
(2) Data usage method: All tifs in the dataset can be loaded directly with ArcGIS software. You can also use the "geotiffread" command in Matlab software to read. Each crop planting area distribution map is 3303 (row) × 3930 (column), and the grid is 0.0025 degrees. The grid value is 0-6, 0 is non-cultivated area, and 1-6 corresponds to 6 types of crops.

background: The North China Plain (NCP) is one of the largest food production areas in China, where cropland takes up more than 80% of this region. Winter wheat and summer maize rotational cultivation is the typical cropping mode, and approximately 75% and 35% of China’s wheat and maize are produced in this region. However, crop water consumption (i.e., evapotranspiration (ET)) is usually higher than precipitation in the winter wheat growing season because of the high crop water consumption and uneven seasonal distribution of precipitation. The multi-year average seasonal ET during the wheat and maize seasons is around 238 mm and 221 mm, respectively, while the respective precipitation is only around 169 mm and 410 mm in the NCP. Thus, irrigation mainly from groundwater or rivers is necessary to favor crop production. However, continuous pumping from groundwater has caused serious overexploitation which led to a dramatic declining trend of groundwater table, especially in the Hebei Plain in the north part of the NCP over the past 40 years. Remote sensing technology has the advantages of providing timely, large coverage and repetitive information and low cost or even free, making it a useful tool to cropland mapping. However, the land use types and cropping systems in the NCP are complicated, manifested by fragmented cropland resulted from highly intensive villages, small towns, and build-up areas with high industrial intensity; various cropping systems and seasonal dynamic patterns caused by the household contract responsivity system which enables peasants to autonomously choose crop species and cultivated time in their fields; the inter-annual fluctuant cropping systems affected by market prices, policies and climate conditions. These complicated tempo-spatial characteristics make large-scale and long-term remote sensing mapping of winter wheat-summer maize remains a challenge.
research objective: Thus, the objectives of this study are to explore a suitable and effective method to map the long-term and large-scale distribution of winter wheat-summer maize in the NCP, based on the supervised classification and MODIS data; analyze the continuous spatio-temporal changes of winter wheat-summer maize from 2001 to 2018.
methods: In this study, MODIS NDVI datasets were analyzed by Fourier transform and maximum likelihood supervised classification to obtain the spatial distribution of winter wheat-summer maize in the NCP and track their changes during 2001 – 2018. The original NDVI data were preprocessed and transformed to the amplitude and phase values by Fourier analysis to be used as the base map for classification. The field survey sites were enriched and eliminated to obtain the final classification sample points. Three classification schemes with different sample categories and temporal resolution of NDVI data were designed and the maximum likelihood supervised classification was applied to discriminate winter wheat and summer maize during 2001 – 2018. The accuracy of the results was evaluated at pixels, county, and regional scales. About the regional level, Landsat images were employed to extract the proportion of winter wheat and summer maize planting area by the threshold method and compared them with the result from MODIS data.
dataset: The data sources in this study consisted of MODIS NDVI datasets, land cover maps, field survey sites, statistic winter wheat acreage data and Landsat images. The MOD09Q1 (MODIS Terra Surface Reflectance 8-Day L3 Global 250 m SIN Grid V006) and MOD13Q1 (MODIS Terra Vegetation Indices 16-Day L3 Global 250 m SIN Grid V006) datasets from 2001 to 2018 were collected from Google Earth Engine (GEE) and Earth Science Data Systems (ESDS) Program, respectively. From 11 to 18 April 2019, a field survey was carried out around the NCP using hand-held GPS. A total of 314 field survey sites, containing 190 winter wheat-summer maize points, 6 cotton points, 13 spring corn points, 13 winter wheat-rice points, 5 pear points and 87 other crop points (e.g., peach and Chinese herbs) were collected. Statistical winter wheat planting area datasets at the county level in 2006, 2013, 2016 and 2017 were gathered from provincial and regional statistical yearbooks from China Statistical Yearbook Database platform. Twelve Landsat images in 2001, 2003, 2016, 2017 and 2018 were downloaded from the EarthExplorer.
findings: The results reveal that using 16-day 0.0025° MODIS NDVI data and six sample categories including winter wheat-summer maize, winter wheat-rice, spring maize, cotton, other one cropping systems and other double cropping systems is an effective way for tracking the variation of winter wheat-summer maize distribution. The winter wheat-summer maize planting area showed an insignificant increasing trend at a rate of 34.2 km²/year (p = 0.955, CV = 7.49%) during 2001 – 2018, while it decreased at the rate of -5065.2 km²/year (p = 0.074) after 2012. Spatially, the planting area shrunk in northern NCP, the piedmont plain of the Taihang Mountains, the west of dry sub-humid zone and the southwest part of the NCP, accounting for 58.6% of the counties during 2001 – 2018; while 17.3% of the counties significantly expanded winter wheat-summer maize in the irrigation district along the Yellow River in Shandong province, the southeast of Hebei Plain and the central humid zone.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting data for agricultural mapping in regions with complex cropping systems?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced in data collection for agricultural mapping in regions with complex cropping systems is the fragmented cropland in the North China Plain, caused by intensive villages, small towns, and areas with high industrial intensity, which complicates the mapping process.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset that might be utilized to enhance the accuracy of remote sensing agricultural maps in the North China Plain?
Example.Answer: A dataset that can be utilized to enhance the accuracy of remote sensing agricultural maps in the North China Plain includes Landsat images, which are used to extract the proportion of winter wheat and summer maize planting areas and compare these with results from MODIS data.

Feature Specification.Question: What attributes of field survey sites are crucial for improving the accuracy of crop classification in agricultural mapping?
Feature Specification.Answer: number and distribution of sample points, various crop types, accurate representation of cropping patterns and conditions

Feature Specification.Question: What are the primary challenges that need to be addressed when using remote sensing data to map complex cropping systems in regions with fragmented landscapes?
Feature Specification.Answer: fragmented cropland, various cropping systems, seasonal dynamic patterns, inter-annual fluctuations in cropping systems

Comparison.Question: How does the use of MODIS NDVI data for crop classification compare to the use of field survey sample points in terms of accuracy and scalability for mapping cropping systems in the North China Plain?
Comparison.Answer: The use of MODIS NDVI data, which involves Fourier transform and maximum likelihood supervised classification, provides large-scale coverage and is timely and cost-effective, making it suitable for tracking long-term cropping system changes. On the other hand, field survey sample points offer ground-truth data which enhances classification accuracy but is limited in spatial coverage and scalability. The combination of both methods improves accuracy, as evidenced by the successful classification of cropping systems from 2001 to 2018 in the North China Plain.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the potential applications of datasets derived from MODIS NDVI data versus those obtained from Landsat images for agricultural water resource management in the North China Plain?
Comparison.Answer: MODIS NDVI data, with its frequent 16-day temporal resolution, is more suited for monitoring seasonal and inter-annual changes in crop distribution, which is essential for timely water resource management and irrigation planning. Landsat images, with higher spatial but lower temporal resolution, are better suited for detailed spatial analysis, such as identifying specific areas of crop stress or changes in land use over longer periods. Each dataset offers unique advantages, with MODIS providing timely updates and Landsat offering detailed spatial insights, both crucial for effective agricultural water resource management.

Interpretation.Question: How can the application of Fourier transform in analyzing MODIS NDVI data improve the accuracy of crop classification in the North China Plain?
Interpretation.Answer: The application of Fourier transform in MODIS NDVI data helps by converting the original data into amplitude and phase values, which serve as a base map for accurate classification. This method enhances the differentiation of crop types by capturing the unique temporal patterns of vegetation indices, leading to a more precise identification of crop distributions in the region.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in using remote sensing technology for mapping the cropping systems in a region with highly fragmented cropland like the North China Plain?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include dealing with the complex land use types and cropping systems caused by small, fragmented parcels of land due to intensive village development and high industrial activity. Additionally, the household contract responsibility system leads to diverse cropping systems and seasonal dynamics, making it difficult to consistently map and track crops over time using remote sensing data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity and challenges of mapping winter wheat-summer maize distribution in the North China Plain using remote sensing data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity and challenges of mapping winter wheat-summer maize distribution in the North China Plain arise from the fragmented cropland due to intensive villages, small towns, and industrial areas, various cropping systems and seasonal dynamic patterns caused by the household contract system, and inter-annual fluctuations influenced by market prices, policies, and climate conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for irrigation in the North China Plain despite the high crop water consumption and uneven precipitation distribution?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Irrigation is necessary in the North China Plain because the crop water consumption (evapotranspiration) during the winter wheat growing season is higher than the precipitation, with multi-year average seasonal ET being around 238 mm while the precipitation is only around 169 mm, necessitating irrigation mainly from groundwater or rivers to support crop production.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might there be discrepancies between remote sensing data and statistical yearbook data when mapping crop distributions in the North China Plain?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Discrepancies between remote sensing data and statistical yearbook data can occur due to the complex land use types and cropping systems in the North China Plain, which are characterized by fragmented cropland and inter-annual fluctuations, making it challenging to achieve consistent large-scale and long-term mapping accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using remote sensing technology for mapping complex cropping systems in the North China Plain over a long-term period?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Remote sensing technology allows for timely, large-scale, and repetitive data collection at low cost, making it possible to track changes in cropping systems with spatial and temporal detail. However, the complex and fragmented nature of the land use in the North China Plain, coupled with diverse cropping systems and dynamic seasonal patterns, presents challenges in achieving accurate and reliable mapping outcomes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of incorporating field survey data and statistical yearbooks on the reliability of crop distribution maps in the North China Plain?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating field survey data and statistical yearbooks can improve the reliability and validation of crop distribution maps by providing ground truth and reference points. This approach helps in refining classification algorithms and accuracy assessments, ensuring that the mapped crop distributions more accurately reflect ground conditions and historical trends.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to analyze the spatio-temporal changes of crop distributions using MODIS data from 2001 to 2018?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Analyzing these changes is crucial for understanding the dynamics of crop planting areas, which can inform strategies for addressing challenges such as groundwater overexploitation and help in developing sustainable agricultural practices within the region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures involved in using MODIS NDVI datasets and Fourier transform for classifying crop distributions in agricultural regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the field, MODIS NDVI datasets are preprocessed and transformed into amplitude and phase values using Fourier analysis to serve as the base map for classification. This involves analyzing the datasets through Fourier transform and applying maximum likelihood supervised classification to obtain spatial distribution data for crops such as winter wheat and summer maize.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can field survey sites be used to enhance the accuracy of crop classification in remote sensing studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Field survey sites are utilized to enrich and refine the classification sample points. A field survey around the North China Plain was conducted using hand-held GPS, collecting data from multiple crop points to inform and validate the supervised classification process, thus enhancing the accuracy of crop distribution mapping.

Enablement.Question: What remote sensing technologies enable the accurate mapping of cropping patterns in complex agricultural regions like the North China Plain?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing technology, particularly the use of MODIS NDVI datasets, enables accurate mapping by providing timely, large coverage information at a low cost. The use of Fourier transform and maximum likelihood supervised classification further refines the mapping of cropping patterns in complex areas such as the North China Plain.

Enablement.Question: What conditions enable the use of statistical yearbook data to validate remote sensing-derived crop distribution maps?
Enablement.Answer: The availability of detailed statistical yearbook data at the county level, such as winter wheat planting area datasets, enables validation of remote sensing-derived maps. These datasets provide a ground-truth reference that can be used to compare and measure the accuracy of crop distribution maps created using tools like MODIS NDVI and Landsat images.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected accuracy of crop distribution mapping in the North China Plain not be achieved through certain remote sensing techniques?
Expectation.Answer: The land use types and cropping systems in the North China Plain are complicated, with fragmented cropland and various cropping systems due to intensive villages, small towns, and high industrial intensity. These complexities, along with seasonal dynamic patterns and inter-annual fluctuations affected by market prices, policies, and climate conditions, make large-scale and long-term remote sensing mapping challenging.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using Fourier transform and maximum likelihood supervised classification for mapping crop distributions in the North China Plain?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of Fourier transform and maximum likelihood supervised classification appears to be effective for mapping crop distributions in the North China Plain. The approach allows for the analysis of long-term and large-scale spatial distribution of typical crops, such as winter wheat and summer maize, with good accuracy. The methods enable the transformation of NDVI data into classification-friendly formats and address the complexity of land use types and cropping systems in the region.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how remote sensing technology can efficiently map the complex cropping systems in the North China Plain.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing technology, particularly using MODIS NDVI datasets, is effective because it provides timely, large coverage, and repetitive information at a low cost. By applying Fourier transform and maximum likelihood supervised classification to these datasets, researchers can map the spatial distribution of crops like winter wheat and summer maize over large scales and track their changes over time despite the complexity of the cropping systems.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the impact of using Fourier transform on MODIS NDVI data for crop classification in the North China Plain.
Request/Directive.Answer: The use of Fourier transform on MODIS NDVI data allows for the transformation of original NDVI data into amplitude and phase values, which are then used as a base map for classification. This method facilitates the accurate classification of winter wheat-summer maize and other crops in the North China Plain, enabling the tracking of their distribution from 2001 to 2018.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges of using remote sensing technologies for mapping cropping systems in the North China Plain.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges of using remote sensing technologies in this context stem from the complex land use types and cropping systems in the North China Plain. These include fragmented cropland due to intensive villages and build-up areas, various cropping systems due to the household contract system, and inter-annual fluctuations influenced by market prices, policies, and climate. These factors complicate large-scale and long-term mapping of winter wheat-summer maize.
